abstract.text: Create a level and assign background and ground elements.

inlineContent.text: Building a game is a time consuming and difficult task. You need to bring together many different elements such as visual assets, game play strategy, challenges, and above all the code to bring this altogether. This is where Scroller2d attempts to help accelerate your ideas by providing a framework and visual editor to create levels in a data driven approach that allows you to modularize your game level core logic.
Every level has repeatable core principles: background, floor (horizontal scrolling), enemies, obstacles, collectibles, checkpoints, and artifacts, etc.

content.text: Scroller2d intent short and long term

inlineContent.text: Is Scroller2d a full fledged 2d game engine?

The quick answer is not currently. It was not initially my intent to develop a gaming engine that would attempt to rival other engines in the market. It was intended to help independent developers and creators to ease the burden of creating a model and modular objects and get to implementing on your ideas. This does not mean that intentions have not changed.
Will Scroller2d become a full fledged 2d game engine?

The longer term answer is a little more involved. The intent long term is to continually add new functionality through classes and helpers that continue to lower the repetitive elements of a game engine design and execution. There is a roadmap, to be released at a future time, to provide a more full featured 2d gaming engine that minimizes the code needed to be manually written, allowing more time to think of new ideas to super-charge your games.

The ObstacleList and CharacterList files are base models that allows Scroller2d to create modularly defined objects.
Some advantages:
Define an obstacle with its base properties and reference multiple times in each level through its ElementNAme property.
Override, through the level data model, any property that is unique for that particular object, such as image name or animation distance.
Used by LevelEditor to provide a visual representation of the object allowing for drag and drop functionality onto the scene.
Scroller2d allows you to represent the various data types needed to create your levels by utilizing a property list implementation and various extension helpers.

A property list only supports a handful of base types such as string, number, boolean, dictionary, and array. Scroller2d extends that representation through the use of extending these base types allowing for the extended use of types such as:
CGPoint
CGSize
CGVector
ClosedRange
Enums
List
Callback functions
You can further explore the various helpers available, under
to use allowing you to convert from one format to another.
How does Scroller2d manage to support data types that cannot be saved directly in a property list file?

As discussed above, Scroller2d offers many different extension helpers to achieve this. When manually entering values into the plist, remember to follow the pattern defined for that particular Scroller2d type to ensure when converted you receive the value in the format you expect.
There are many helper extensions that help you solve common issues from size to point to enumerated lists.
Explore
to get a fuller list of extensions available for use with the data types. The String extension has the most helpers providing the most extensive conversions to various data types.

Enumeration list
In addition to offering a data model, Scroller2d offers an object model as well. It provides base functionality for the scene such as providing a way to cache SKTexture lists to improve performance.
Is this all that you offer as far as class helpers?
Currently yes. As explained above, the goal is to continue to add targeted class helpers that continue to help make your job easier allowing your creativity to shine.
